Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: The roster is tight today and the coordinator reminded everyone that each role starts as soon as the doors open.
Story: My phone buzzed as I laced up my shoes, ready to head out for my Saturday morning volunteer shift. The message was from my stepdad: “Hey, haven’t heard from you in a while. Hope you’re okay. Can you call us this weekend?” I stared at the screen, guilt prickling at my chest. I knew how much it meant to my parents that I checked in, especially since I moved out. But the volunteer coordinator had just sent a group text, reminding us that the shelter was short-staffed and every minute counted. “Please be on time—doors open at 9 sharp,” she wrote. I glanced at the clock. If I called my parents now, I’d be late. If I waited until after my shift, I’d be breaking my promise to keep in touch. My thumb hovered over the call button, my mind torn between the family that wanted to hear my voice and the people counting on me to show up.
